maml:description.maml:para: Specifies additional base-64 encoded XML formatted information that can be included in the Unattend.xml file, which is used by Windows Setup.
Specifies additional base-64 encoded XML formatted information that can be included in the Unattend.xml file, which is used by Windows Setup.
VM object to modify. Create one using New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or Get one using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.

Specifies the base-64 encoded XML formatted content that is added to the unattend.xml file for the specified path and component. The XML must be less that 4 KB and must include the root element for the setting or feature that is being inserted.
Specifies the name of the setting to which the content applies.
VM object to modify. Create one using New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or Get one using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.

Specifies the base-64 encoded XML formatted content that is added to the unattend.xml file for the specified path and component. The XML must be less that 4 KB and must include the root element for the setting or feature that is being inserted.
Specifies the name of the setting to which the content applies.
This cmdlets allows you to add a Data Disk to the VM at creation time or to an existing VM
Local VM Object to add the Data Disk to. The local VM object can be created with New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or gotten through the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the VHD file that needs to be created when a platform image or user image is used. This is where the image blob will be copied to start the VM from.

Specifies the caching mode of the disk. This setting impacts the consistency and performance of the disk. Note: Changing this value causes the Virtual Machine to reboot. Possible values are: • ReadOnly • ReadWrite The default value is ReadWrite.
Specifies the size, in GB, of an empty disk to be attached to the Virtual Machine.

Specifies the Logical Unit Number (LUN) for the data disk. If the disk is the first disk that is added, this element is optional and the default value of 0 is used. If more than one disk is being added, this element is required.
Specifies whether to create a disk in the VM from a platform or user image, to create a new empty disk or to attach an existing disk. Valid values are
Uri of the existing VHD in case attaching the disk to the VM
Local VM Object to add the Data Disk to. The local VM object can be created with New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or gotten through the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the VHD file that needs to be created when a platform image or user image is used. This is where the image blob will be copied to start the VM from.

Specifies the caching mode of the disk. This setting impacts the consistency and performance of the disk. Note: Changing this value causes the Virtual Machine to reboot. Possible values are: • ReadOnly • ReadWrite The default value is ReadWrite.
Specifies the size, in GB, of an empty disk to be attached to the Virtual Machine.

Specifies the Logical Unit Number (LUN) for the data disk. If the disk is the first disk that is added, this element is optional and the default value of 0 is used. If more than one disk is being added, this element is required.
Specifies whether to create a disk in the VM from a platform or user image, to create a new empty disk or to attach an existing disk. Valid values are
Uri of the existing VHD in case attaching the disk to the VM

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Add Data Disk to a new VM --------------------------
-------------------------- Add a Data Disk to an existing VM --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Add a Network Interface to the VM
This cmdlets allows you to add a NIC to the VM at creation time or to an existing VM
Local VM Object to add the Network Interface to. The local VM object can be created with New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or gotten through the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Id of the Network Interface. This can be gotten using the Get-AzureNetworkInterface cmdlet.
Local VM Object to add the Network Interface to. The local VM object can be created with New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or gotten through the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Id of the Network Interface. This can be gotten using the Get-AzureNetworkInterface cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Add a Network Interface to a new VM --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Get the VM $vm = Get-AzureVM -ResourceGroupName "myRG" -Name "crpVM
# Add a Network Interface to the VM Add-AzureVMNetworkInterface –VM $vm –Id "/subscriptions/subscriptionId/resourceGroups/resourceGroupName/providers/Microsoft.Network/NetworkAdapters/Nic1"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Add a Network Interface to an existing VM --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Get the VM $vm = Get-AzureVM -ResourceGroupName "myRG" -Name "crpVM"
# Add a Network Interface to the VM Add-AzureVMNetworkInterface –VM $vm –Id "/subscriptions/subscriptionId/resourceGroups/resourceGroupName/providers/Microsoft.Network/NetworkAdapters/Nic1"
# Update VM state Update-AzureVM -ResourceGroupName "myRG" -Name "crpVM" –VM $vm

maml:description.maml:para: Add a secret to the VM which allows you to place a certificate on the VM
Add a secret to the VM which allows you to place a certificate on the VM
VM object to modify. Create one using New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or Get one using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.

Resource Id of the Key Vault which contains the certificates to place on the VM. Also acts as the key for adding multiple certificates i.e. use the same SourceVaultId when adding multiple certificates from the same KeyVault
Name of the certificate store on the Windows VM the certificate should be added to
A KeyVault Url pointing to a KeyVault secret which contains a certificate formatted as follows
It is the Base64 encoding of the following JSON Object which is encoded in UTF-8
VM object to modify. Create one using New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or Get one using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.

Resource Id of the Key Vault which contains the certificates to place on the VM. Also acts as the key for adding multiple certificates i.e. use the same SourceVaultId when adding multiple certificates from the same KeyVault
Name of the certificate store on the Windows VM the certificate should be added to
A KeyVault Url pointing to a KeyVault secret which contains a certificate formatted as follows
It is the Base64 encoding of the following JSON Object which is encoded in UTF-8
Specifies the SSH public keys to use with the Virtual Machine.
Specifies the SSH public keys to use with the Virtual Machine.
VM object to modify. Create one using New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or Get one using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies a base-64 encoding of the public key used to SSH into the Virtual Machine.

Specifies the full path of a file, on the Virtual Machine, where the SSH public key is stored. If the file already exists, the specified key is appended to the file. Example: /home/user/.ssh/authorized_keys
VM object to modify. Create one using New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet or Get one using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies a base-64 encoding of the public key used to SSH into the Virtual Machine.

Specifies the full path of a file, on the Virtual Machine, where the SSH public key is stored. If the file already exists, the specified key is appended to the file. Example: /home/user/.ssh/authorized_keys

Get the properties of a Storage Account
This cmdlet allows you to get the properties of a specified Storage Account or all Storage Accounts within a Resource Group or the subscription.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Get a specified storage account --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> #Get one storage account Get-AzureStorageAccount -ResourceGroupName "RG1" -AccountName "myStorageAccount"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Get all Storage Accounts in a Resource Group --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> # Get all Storage Accounts in a Resource Group Get-AzureStorageAccount -ResourceGroupName "RG1"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Get all Storage Accounts in the subscription --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> # Get all Storage Accounts in the subscription Get-AzureStorageAccount

maml:description.maml:para: Get the access keys for an Azure storage account
This cmdlet allows you to get the access keys for an Azure storage account.
Get the properties of a VM or Get all VMs in a subscription
This cmdlet allows you to get the model or instance view of the VM. By default the returned VM object contains the model view. If you'd like to see the instance view of a VM use the -Status switch.
This cmdlet also allows you to get information about all VMs in your subscription if no parameters are used.
Allows you to only return the Instance View
Allows you to only return the Instance View

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Get only the status of VM --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get the VM instance view $vm = Get-AzureVM -ResourceGroupName "myRG" -Name "crpVM" -Status

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Get all VMs in a Resource Group --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Get all VMs in a Resource Group $vm = Get-AzureVM -ResourceGroupName "myRG"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Get all VMs in your subscription --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Get all VMs in your subscription Get-AzureVM

This cmdlet allows you to create an Availability Set
Allows you to create a new Storage Account
This cmdlet allows you to create a new Storage Account.

Type of Storage Account. Valid values are • Standard_LRS (Locally-redundant storage) • Standard_ZRS (Zone-redundant storage) • Standard_GRS (Geo-redundant storage) • Standard_RAGRS (Read access geo-redundant storage)

Type of Storage Account. Valid values are • Standard_LRS (Locally-redundant storage) • Standard_ZRS (Zone-redundant storage) • Standard_GRS (Geo-redundant storage) • Standard_RAGRS (Read access geo-redundant storage)
Regenerates a storage key for an Azure storage account.
Regenerates a storage key for an Azure storage account.
Name of the Resource Group the storage account is in
Specifies which key to regenerate. Supported value set: - “key1” - “key2”
Name of the Resource Group the storage account is in
Specifies which key to regenerate. Supported value set: - “key1” - “key2”

This cmdlet allows you to create a new VM in Azure. This cmdlet takes a VM object as input which can be created using the New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet. The VM object must then be configured correctly using appropriate cmdlets such as Set-AzureVMOperatingSystem, Set-AzureVMSourceImage, Set-AzureVMNetworkInterface etc. before the VM can be created in Azure succesfully.

VM object that is configured and represents the state of the VM to be created. The VM object can be created using the New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet. The VM object must then be configured correctly using appropriate cmdlets such as Set-AzureVMOperatingSystem, Set-AzureVMSourceImage, Set-AzureVMNetworkInterface etc. before the VM can be created in Azure succesfully.

VM object that is configured and represents the state of the VM to be created. The VM object can be created using the New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet. The VM object must then be configured correctly using appropriate cmdlets such as Set-AzureVMOperatingSystem, Set-AzureVMSourceImage, Set-AzureVMNetworkInterface etc. before the VM can be created in Azure succesfully.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Create a VM with two Data Disks --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Create the configurable local VM Object

This cmdlet allows you to create the configurable local VM Object. The VM object must then be configured correctly using appropriate cmdlets such as Set-AzureVMOperatingSystem, Set-AzureVMSourceImage, Set-AzureVMNetworkInterface etc. before the VM can be created in Azure succesfully.
Id of the Availability Set. This can be gotten through Get-AzureAvailabilitySet cmdlet.
Id of the Availability Set. This can be gotten through Get-AzureAvailabilitySet cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Create a new VM Object --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Get the Availability Set $as = Get-AzureAvailabilitySet –ResourceGroupName “RG1” –Name “MyASet”
# Create the VM object $vm = New-AzureVMConfig –VMName “myVM” –VMSize “Standard_A1" -AvailabilitySetID $as.Id

Remove a Data Disk from the VM
This cmdlet allows you to remove a Data Disk from the VM
Local VM object to remove the Data Disk from. This object can be gotten from the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Name of the Data Disk to be removed
Local VM object to remove the Data Disk from. This object can be gotten from the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Name of the Data Disk to be removed

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Remove a Data Disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> # Get the VM $vm = Get-AzureVM -ResourceGroupName "myRG" -Name "crpVM"
# Remove "disk3" Data Disk from the local object Remove-AzureVMDataDisk -VM $vm -Name 'disk3'
# Update the state of the Azure VM Update-AzureVM -ResourceGroupName "myRG" -Name "crpVM" –VM $vm

maml:description.maml:para: Remove an Extension from a VM
Remove an extension from a VM
Remove the network interface from the VM
Remove the network interface from the VM
Allows you to capture your VM as a VMImage
Allows you to capture your VM as a VMImage. Required step before this is to sysprep the VM and mark it generalized using the Set-AzureVM -Generalize cmdlet.
The output is a JSON template that can be used to deploy from your captured image.

This is the name of the container inside which the vhds constituting the VMImage will reside. If they are spread across multiple storage accounts, one container with this name will be created in each storage account.
This is the prefix in the name of the blobs that will constitute the storage profile of the VMImage. For e.g. the OSDisk can be named vhdPrefix-osdisk
Indicates if any vhds with same Prefix inside the destination Container are encountered, should they be overwritten or not.

This is the name of the container inside which the vhds constituting the VMImage will reside. If they are spread across multiple storage accounts, one container with this name will be created in each storage account.
This is the prefix in the name of the blobs that will constitute the storage profile of the VMImage. For e.g. the OSDisk can be named vhdPrefix-osdisk
Indicates if any vhds with same Prefix inside the destination Container are encountered, should they be overwritten or not.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Captures the VMImage. The Output property returns a JSON template that can be used to deploy from the captured VMImage.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet allows you to update the Storage Account properties.

Specifies the account type of the storage account. One of four options: • Standard_LRS (Locally-redundant storage) • Standard_GRS (Geo-redundant storage) • Standard_RAGRS (Read access geo-redundant storage) • Standard_ZRS
Note that Standard_ZRS accounts cannot be changed to other account types, and other account types cannot be changed to Standard_ZRS.
The name of the custom domain.

Specifies the account type of the storage account. One of four options: • Standard_LRS (Locally-redundant storage) • Standard_GRS (Geo-redundant storage) • Standard_RAGRS (Read access geo-redundant storage) • Standard_ZRS
Note that Standard_ZRS accounts cannot be changed to other account types, and other account types cannot be changed to Standard_ZRS.
The name of the custom domain.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Set Storage Account type --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> # Set account type Set-AzureStorageAccount -ResourceGroupName "myResourceGroup" -AccountName "myStorageAccount" -AccountType "Standard_RAGRS"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Set Custom Domain --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> #Set custom domain Set-AzureStorageAccount -ResourceGroupName "myResourceGroup" -AccountName "myStorageAccount" -CustomDomainName "domain name" –UseSubDomain “true”

maml:description.maml:para: Set the OS properties for the VM
This cmdlet allows you to set the OS properties such as login credentials, computer name etc.
The local VM object to set the OS properties on
Specify the type of OS is Windows
PSCredential object that contains username and password for the VM

Specifies a base-64 encoded string of custom data. The base-64 encoded string is decoded to a binary array that is saved as a file on the Virtual Machine. The maximum length of the binary array is 65535 bytes.
Linux - The file is copied to /var/lib/waagent/ovf-env.xml by the Azure Linux Agent. The agent will also place the base-64 encoded data in /var/lib/waagent/CustomData during provisioning.
Windows – The file is saved to %SYSTEMDRIVE%\AzureData\CustomData.bin. If the file exists, it is overwritten. The security on directory is set to System:Full Control and Administrators:Full Control.
Indicates that the VM agent should be installed on the VM
URL of certificate in KeyVault to be used for WinRM HTTPS
The local VM object to set the OS properties on
Specify the type of OS is Linux
PSCredential object that contains username and password for the VM

Specifies a base-64 encoded string of custom data. The base-64 encoded string is decoded to a binary array that is saved as a file on the Virtual Machine. The maximum length of the binary array is 65535 bytes.
Linux - The file is copied to /var/lib/waagent/ovf-env.xml by the Azure Linux Agent. The agent will also place the base-64 encoded data in /var/lib/waagent/CustomData during provisioning.
Windows – The file is saved to %SYSTEMDRIVE%\AzureData\CustomData.bin. If the file exists, it is overwritten. The security on directory is set to System:Full Control and Administrators:Full Control.
The local VM object to set the OS properties on
Specify the type of OS is Windows
PSCredential object that contains username and password for the VM

Specifies a base-64 encoded string of custom data. The base-64 encoded string is decoded to a binary array that is saved as a file on the Virtual Machine. The maximum length of the binary array is 65535 bytes.
Linux - The file is copied to /var/lib/waagent/ovf-env.xml by the Azure Linux Agent. The agent will also place the base-64 encoded data in /var/lib/waagent/CustomData during provisioning.
Windows – The file is saved to %SYSTEMDRIVE%\AzureData\CustomData.bin. If the file exists, it is overwritten. The security on directory is set to System:Full Control and Administrators:Full Control.
Indicates that the VM agent should be installed on the VM
URL of certificate in KeyVault to be used for WinRM HTTPS
Specify the type of OS is Linux
Secrets config that specifies the source KeyVault and Certificate url. Use the Add-AzureVMSecret cmdlet to create this config.
AdditionalUnattendContent config. Use the Add-AzureVMAdditionalUnattendContent cmdlet to create this.
SSH public key for the VM

maml:description.maml:para: Set the OS Disk properties on the VM
Set the OS Disk properties on the VM
The local VM object to set the OS Disk properties on

For Image based VM Creation – Specifies the VHD file that needs to be created when a platform image or user image is specified. This is where the image blob will be copied to start the VM from. Example: http://contoso.blob.core.windows.net/System/ComputeVM/myImage/mydisk.vhd
For Disk based VM Boot scenario – Specifies the VHD file that needs to be used directly (without copy) for booting up the VM. Applies to both OS and Data Disks.

Specifies the caching mode of the operating system disk. This setting impacts the consistency and performance of the disk. Note: Changing this value causes the Virtual Machine to reboot. Possible values are: The default value is ReadWrite. • ReadOnly • ReadWrite
Uri of the existing VHD in case attaching the disk to the VM
Specifies whether to create a disk in the VM from a platform or user image, to create a new empty disk or to attach an existing disk. Valid values are
Used in case of a user image based VM deployment to specify that the OS on the user image is Windows.
The local VM object to set the OS Disk properties on

For Image based VM Creation – Specifies the VHD file that needs to be created when a platform image or user image is specified. This is where the image blob will be copied to start the VM from. Example: http://contoso.blob.core.windows.net/System/ComputeVM/myImage/mydisk.vhd
For Disk based VM Boot scenario – Specifies the VHD file that needs to be used directly (without copy) for booting up the VM. Applies to both OS and Data Disks.

Specifies the caching mode of the operating system disk. This setting impacts the consistency and performance of the disk. Note: Changing this value causes the Virtual Machine to reboot. Possible values are: The default value is ReadWrite. • ReadOnly • ReadWrite
Uri of the existing VHD in case attaching the disk to the VM
Specifies whether to create a disk in the VM from a platform or user image, to create a new empty disk or to attach an existing disk. Valid values are
Used in case of a user image based VM deployment to specify that the OS on the user image is Linux.
The local VM object to set the OS Disk properties on

For Image based VM Creation – Specifies the VHD file that needs to be created when a platform image or user image is specified. This is where the image blob will be copied to start the VM from. Example: http://contoso.blob.core.windows.net/System/ComputeVM/myImage/mydisk.vhd
For Disk based VM Boot scenario – Specifies the VHD file that needs to be used directly (without copy) for booting up the VM. Applies to both OS and Data Disks.

Specifies the caching mode of the operating system disk. This setting impacts the consistency and performance of the disk. Note: Changing this value causes the Virtual Machine to reboot. Possible values are: The default value is ReadWrite. • ReadOnly • ReadWrite
Uri of the existing VHD in case attaching the disk to the VM
Specifies whether to create a disk in the VM from a platform or user image, to create a new empty disk or to attach an existing disk. Valid values are
Used in case of a user image based VM deployment to specify that the OS on the user image is Windows.
Used in case of a user image based VM deployment to specify that the OS on the user image is Linux.
Specify the VM Image to be used for the VM
Specify the VM Image to be used for the VM
The local VM object to be configured
Name of the Publisher to be used for the VMImage. Can be discovered using the Get-AzureVMImagePublisher cmdlet
Name of the Offer to be used for the VMImage. Can be discovered using the Get-AzureVMImageOffer cmdlet
Name of the SKU to be used for the VMImage. Can be discovered using the Get-AzureVMImageSku cmdlet
Name of the Version to be used for the VMImage. Can be discovered using the Get-AzureVMImage cmdlet
The local VM object to be configured
The local VM object to be configured
Name of the Publisher to be used for the VMImage. Can be discovered using the Get-AzureVMImagePublisher cmdlet
Name of the Offer to be used for the VMImage. Can be discovered using the Get-AzureVMImageOffer cmdlet
Name of the SKU to be used for the VMImage. Can be discovered using the Get-AzureVMImageSku cmdlet
Name of the Version to be used for the VMImage. Can be discovered using the Get-AzureVMImage cmdlet
Image reference to use for the VM. This is an object that can be passed in from the return of the Get-AzureVMImage or the Get-AzureVMImageDetail cmdlet
Container to be used for storing VHDs while creating a VM from platform image. Container will be created by CRP if it doesn’t exist already.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Create the VM object $vm = New-AzureVMConfig –VMName “myVM” –VMSize “Standard_A1"
# Set the PublisherName, Offer, SKU, Version which can be discovered by the Get-AzureVMImagePublisher, Get-AzureVMImageOffer, Get-AzureVMSku, Get-AzureVMImage cmdlets Set-AzureVMSourceImage -VM $vm -PublisherName MicrosoftWindowsServer -Offer WindowsServer -Skus 2012-R2-Datacenter -Version "latest"

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet allows you to start a VM
This cmdlet allows you to Stop a VM
This cmdlet allows you to update the Azure VM state with the state of the local VM object
The local VM object that contains the updating VM state
The local VM object that contains the updating VM state
